content.heading: Acoustic Manipulation of Biological Samples: A Survey
Abstract
content.content: This survey paper comprehensively examines the advancements and applications of acoustic manipulation techniques in biomedical research, focusing on their transformative potential for biological sample control, diagnostics, and therapeutics. We systematically review the foundational principles of acoustic forces, including primary radiation and secondary Bjerknes forces, which enable noncontact precision manipulation of cells and biomolecules through devices such as acoustic tweezers and acoustofluidic systems. The integration of these technologies with microfluidics and lab-on-a-chip platforms has revolutionized single-cell analysis, offering high-throughput, label-free sorting while preserving cellular integrity. Key applications span enhanced imaging via microbubble technology, targeted drug delivery, and tissue engineering, supported by innovations like holographic amplitude modulation and transmodal Fabry-Pérot resonance. Despite these advancements, challenges persist in scalability, material compatibility, and computational modeling, necessitating interdisciplinary collaboration to optimize transducer design, standardize protocols, and integrate machine learning for adaptive control. The paper concludes by outlining future directions, emphasizing the convergence of acoustic manipulation with organ-on-chip systems and precision medicine to address critical biomedical challenges.

content.heading: 1 Introduction
content.content: The field of biomedical research has witnessed a remarkable evolution with the advent of novel techniques that enhance the precision and efficacy of experimental methodologies. Among these, acoustic manipulation stands out as a transformative approach, employing sound waves to achieve non-invasive control over biological samples. This review aims to articulate the significance of acoustic manipulation in various biomedical applications, including diagnostics, therapeutics, and single-cell analysis. By exploring the underlying principles and technological advancements, we can better appreciate the potential of acoustic methods in addressing critical challenges in the biomedical field. The subsequent sections will delve deeper into the specific applications and implications of these techniques, providing a comprehensive overview of their impact on research and clinical practices.

content.heading: 1.1 Significance of Acoustic Manipulation in Biomedical Research
content.content:
Acoustic manipulation techniques have revolutionized biomedical research by enabling precise, noncontact control of biological samples at microscales. These methods, including acoustic tweezers and acoustofluidic separation, leverage the physical principles of sound waves to manipulate cells and biomolecules with minimal invasiveness, addressing critical challenges in diagnostics, therapeutics, and single-cell analysis. The integration of ultrasound-based approaches has been particularly transformative, offering high-resolution real-time visualization for interventional surgical procedures [1] and enhancing the quality of image reconstruction in diagnostic applications [2]. The ability to manipulate biological systems without direct contact not only preserves sample integrity but also opens avenues for innovative experimental designs.

In diagnostics, acoustic manipulation has significantly improved the efficiency and portability of lab-on-a-chip platforms. The ability to generate reconfigurable ultrasound fields in real time [3] has expanded the potential for targeted imaging and therapeutic delivery. Advanced focusing techniques, such as those employing holograms [4], further enhance the precision of ultrasonic applications in medical devices. These innovations are complemented by the development of acoustic diodes [5], which enable unidirectional wave propagation for improved control in biomedical systems. As a result, the incorporation of acoustic manipulation into diagnostic tools has the potential to enhance patient outcomes by facilitating more accurate and timely interventions.

Therapeutic applications benefit from acoustic manipulation through optimized drug delivery systems and microbubble technology. Studies on phospholipid-stabilized nanobubbles [6] demonstrate the role of acoustic forces in enhancing contrast-enhanced ultrasound and targeted therapy. The intersection of acoustics with chemiluminescence [5] further opens new avenues for energy-efficient biomedical sensors and actuators, highlighting the versatility of acoustic methods in therapeutic contexts. This multifaceted approach not only improves the efficacy of existing therapies but also paves the way for the development of novel therapeutic modalities that leverage acoustic principles for enhanced performance.

Single-cell analysis has been profoundly impacted by acoustic manipulation, particularly in addressing cellular heterogeneity and advancing precision medicine [7]. The integration of deep learning approaches [8] and multimodal AI frameworks [2] with acoustic sorting techniques has enabled unprecedented insights into gene regulation and disease mechanisms [6]. Non-invasive techniques for probing chemical dynamics at the single-cell level, such as NMR spectroscopy [9], further underscore the interdisciplinary potential of acoustic manipulation. Theoretical advancements in representing and extracting knowledge from single-cell data [10] also highlight the role of acoustic methods in bridging gaps in topology and generative processes. Future directions include refining device scalability, improving material compatibility, and integrating acoustic techniques with emerging computational tools to address current limitations in reproducibility and operational efficiency.

The relevance of acoustic manipulation in biomedical research cannot be overstated, as it presents innovative solutions to longstanding challenges within the field. From enhancing diagnostic capabilities to improving therapeutic delivery and enabling precise single-cell analysis, the applications of acoustic techniques are vast and varied. The continuous evolution of these methods, coupled with advancements in technology and interdisciplinary collaboration, promises to further expand their utility in biomedical research. As the field progresses, it will be essential to explore the implications of these advancements and their potential to transform clinical practices and patient care.

content.heading: 1.2 Structure of the Survey
content.content:
This survey systematically examines the advancements and applications of acoustic manipulation in biological research, organized into eight cohesive sections. Section 1 introduces the significance of acoustic manipulation techniques in biomedical engineering, emphasizing their transformative potential in diagnostics, therapeutics, and single-cell analysis. Section 2 establishes the foundational principles of acoustic forces and their interaction with biological samples, covering the physics of sound waves [2], acoustic tweezers [3], and the integration of acoustofluidics with microfluidic systems [6]. This foundational understanding is critical for appreciating the subsequent discussions on specific applications and innovations.

Section 3 delves into the design and operational mechanisms of acoustic tweezers for biomolecules, highlighting their non-contact precision and versatility in biological applications [4]. By elucidating the underlying principles of these devices, this section aims to provide insights into their operational capabilities and potential for future developments. Section 4 explores acoustofluidic separation techniques, detailing their underlying mechanisms and their role in advancing single-cell analysis platforms. The combination of acoustics with fluid dynamics represents a significant leap forward in the ability to isolate and analyze individual cells, thereby enhancing our understanding of cellular behavior and heterogeneity.

Section 5 discusses the integration of acoustic manipulation with microfluidics and lab-on-a-chip technology, showcasing the benefits of miniaturization through case studies [7]. The synergy between these technologies facilitates the development of compact and efficient diagnostic tools, which are essential in modern biomedical research. Section 6 reviews practical applications in biomedical engineering, including drug delivery [5], tissue engineering, and diagnostics enhanced by microbubble technology [9]. This comprehensive review of applications underscores the versatility and efficacy of acoustic methods in addressing diverse biomedical challenges.

Section 7 identifies current challenges, such as scalability and material limitations, and proposes future directions, including computational advancements [8] and interdisciplinary collaboration [2]. The recognition of these challenges is crucial for guiding future research efforts and ensuring the continued advancement of acoustic manipulation techniques. The survey concludes with a synthesis of key findings and emerging opportunities in Section 8, emphasizing the importance of ongoing research in this dynamic field and the potential for acoustic manipulation to shape the future of biomedical engineering.The following sections are organized as shown in Figure 1.

content.heading: 2.1 Physics of Sound Waves and Acoustic Forces
content.content:
Acoustic manipulation in biomedical contexts is grounded in the principles of sound wave propagation and their interaction with matter. Sound waves, as mechanical vibrations, create periodic compressions and rarefactions in a medium, described by parameters such as frequency, amplitude, and wavelength. In medicine, these principles underpin technologies like ultrasound imaging and therapeutic ultrasound. Nonlinear acoustic phenomena, including harmonic generation and acoustic streaming, are crucial in biomedical applications, modeled by the Westervelt equation [11]. The Transmodal Fabry-Pérot Resonance (TFPR) principle enhances energy transfer efficiency by leveraging phase differences between coupled wave modes [4], allowing precise control over wave transmission.

Acoustic forces manifest as primary radiation and secondary Bjerknes forces. The primary radiation force, resulting from wave scattering, enables precise particle trapping, essential in acoustic tweezers [12]. The secondary Bjerknes force, from interparticle scattering, aids in particle aggregation or separation based on size and compressibility, with MHz-range frequencies effective for microscale manipulation [5]. Techniques like wave momentum shaping optimize momentum transfer in complex media [13], significantly impacting diagnostics and therapeutics.

The viscoelastic properties of the medium and target particles influence acoustic manipulation efficiency. The shell composition of lipid-coated microbubbles affects their acoustic response, with additives modulating viscoelasticity [6]. Biodegradable polymers such as PLA and PLGA exhibit unique acoustic properties, suitable for tissue engineering [4]. Nonlinear materials in devices introduce additional control over wave propagation [5]. Addressing challenges in shape asymmetry of sub-wavelength objects requires refined models [4]. Advanced modeling techniques, such as the mixed finite element method, improve accuracy in heterogeneous environments [10]. Integrating machine learning with acoustic research promises enhanced understanding of complex interactions within biological systems.

Advancements in universal algorithms for cell segmentation [3] and Bayesian modeling for singlecell data [10] will refine acoustic manipulation techniques. Innovations in ultrasound sources with amplitude masks [3] and neural network-enhanced localization [1] promise improved precision. Future research should optimize transducer design, material selection, and algorithmic precision to address scalability and reproducibility challenges, particularly in cellular heterogeneity [7]. Exploring these areas is essential for advancing acoustic manipulation in medicine and biotechnology.

content.heading: 2.2 Acoustic Tweezers and Ultrasonic Particle Manipulation
content.content:
Acoustic tweezers and ultrasonic particle manipulation offer non-contact precision handling of biological samples, utilizing standing surface acoustic waves (SAWs) in microfluidic environments. Modulating ultrasound emitter phases and frequencies enables dynamic particle trapping and translation [12]. The Fast Acoustic Tweezers (FAT) system exemplifies this, allowing rapid reconfigurability for two-dimensional manipulation [12]. The use of primary radiation and secondary Bjerknes forces enables precise spatial control. Acoustic Shadow Moiré Interference (ASMI) combines wave interference patterns with ultrasound penetration for simultaneous imaging and manipulation [12]. Willis coupling-induced acoustic radiation improves manipulation of asymmetrical shapes [4].

Piezoelectric transducer technology, through electrophoretic deposition (EPD) of PZT thick films, enhances device implementation [5]. The TFPR principle optimizes energy transfer by coupling wave modes [4]. Wave momentum shaping techniques enable manipulation in complex media [13]. Holographic amplitude modulation with ultrasound sources generates reconfigurable field patterns [3]. Stiffness mapping techniques quantify membrane deformation under acoustic pressure [6]. Ultrasound Electrical Impedance Spectroscopy (UEIS) characterizes biological samples during manipulation [8].

Computational modeling advances, including mixed finite element formulations, provide insights into wave-particle interactions [10]. Kernel-based statistical frameworks analyze differential responses across manipulated cell populations [1]. Future directions include integrating machine learning with real-time acoustic field modulation to address cellular heterogeneity. These developments are crucial for advancing acoustic manipulation in complex biological environments.

content.heading: 2.3 Acoustofluidic Separation and Microfluidics
content.content:
Acoustofluidic separation techniques integrated with microfluidic systems have transformed biological sample manipulation, combining precise acoustic force control with lab-on-a-chip scalability. Ultrasonic standing waves sort cells or particles based on size, density, or compressibility, enabling high-throughput separation [12]. Microfluidic acoustophoresis achieves label-free sorting, directing targets toward pressure nodes or antinodes [2]. This non-invasive method preserves cell viability, enhancing throughput and enabling parallel processing [12].

Advanced signal processing models refine acoustofluidic separation by compensating for noise and artifacts in microscale environments. Hybrid approaches combining model-based reconstructions with deep learning improve particle trajectory predictions [2]. Impedance spectroscopy with acoustophoresis enables real-time monitoring of separation efficacy [12]. Challenges in scaling devices for clinical applications involve maintaining consistency across manufacturing and handling biofouling. Future directions include disposable microfluidic cartridges with advanced piezoelectric actuators and multimodal sensing technologies for real-time monitoring and control [5, 12, 11, 5]. Innovations in material science and algorithmic improvements will further bridge the gap between laboratory research and commercial biomedical systems.

content.heading: 3 Acoustic Tweezers for Biomolecules
content.content:
Recent advancements in acoustic tweezers technology have significantly enhanced the manipulation of biomolecules, offering precise control over microscale entities. This section explores the fundamental principles of acoustic tweezers, which utilize ultrasonic waves to exert targeted forces on particles. Understanding these principles and mechanisms is crucial for appreciating their capabilities and limitations, as well as their transformative potential in diagnostics, therapeutics, and biological research.

content.heading: 3.1 Principles of Acoustic Tweezers
content.content:
Acoustic tweezers employ ultrasonic waves for non-contact manipulation of microscale particles with sub-micrometer precision. The primary radiation force, based on wave scattering, is influenced by the compressibility and density contrast between the particle and medium, as described by the Gor’kov potential [12]. While traditional models assume spherical symmetry, recent advancements incorporate shape asymmetry through polarizability tensors with Willis coupling coefficients, enhancing applicability to irregularly shaped biological specimens [4]. This allows for precise torque generation and orientation control, crucial for manipulating anisotropic biomolecules and cellular aggregates.

Piezoelectric transducers, often fabricated using electrophoretic deposition (EPD), optimize lead zirconate titanate (PZT) microstructure for enhanced resonance [5]. Holographic amplitude modulation, such as translating masks over fixed ultrasound sources, facilitates dynamic reconfiguration of pressure fields for real-time particle manipulation [3]. The Transmodal Fabry-Pérot Resonance (TFPR) principle further improves energy transfer efficiency by coupling longitudinal and shear wave modes, enhancing manipulation stability in viscoelastic media [4].

Operational advantages include simultaneous mechanical characterization during manipulation. Ultrasound Electrical Impedance Spectroscopy (UEIS) provides real-time feedback on particle stiffness and interfacial properties [8]. Holographic cell stiffness mapping quantifies membrane deformation under acoustic pressure, revealing spatial heterogeneity in mechanical properties [6]. Kernelbased statistical frameworks, like Kernel Fisher Discriminant Analysis (KFDA), differentiate cellular responses based on acoustic manipulation data [1]. These advancements enhance our understanding of material properties and pave the way for refined applications in cell biology and material science.

Machine learning and advanced computational techniques promise further advancements in acoustic tweezers. Future developments focus on integrating machine learning for adaptive field modulation, utilizing neural networks trained on particle trajectory datasets [1]. Multimodal AI frameworks may bridge acoustic manipulation with single-cell omics, as demonstrated by systems combining acoustofluidics with Raman spectroscopy for concurrent trapping and molecular profiling [12]. Addressing scalability challenges requires advances in transducer miniaturization and standardized fabrication protocols to transition from laboratory prototypes to clinical-grade devices.

content.heading: 3.2 Applications in Biomolecule Manipulation
content.content:
Acoustic tweezers exhibit remarkable versatility in manipulating biomolecules, from nucleic acids to extracellular vesicles, with applications in diagnostics, therapeutics, and biological research. Figure 3 illustrates key applications of acoustic tweezers in biomolecule manipulation, categorized into diagnostics and research, therapeutics, and emerging technologies, highlighting innovative systems and techniques. The Fast Acoustic Tweezers (FAT) system exemplifies this capability, achieving rapid two-dimensional positioning of microspheres and cells with sub-micrometer precision and millisecond-scale reconfiguration times [12]. This precision facilitates the isolation and analysis of rare cell populations, as demonstrated by Raman-acoustofluidic platforms that integrate acoustic trapping with spectroscopic profiling for single-cell resolution [12].

The manipulation of lipid-coated microbubbles showcases the technique’s therapeutic potential, where shell composition-dependent pressure thresholds govern nonlinear oscillations crucial for ultrasound contrast enhancement and targeted drug delivery [6]. Acoustic tweezers address traditional limitations in handling asymmetrical particles through Willis coupling-induced radiation forces, facilitating orientation control of fibrous proteins or rod-shaped bacteria [4].

Single-cell RNA sequencing benefits from acoustic preprocessing, with confident clustering algorithms and PCA compression reducing misclassification errors during cell type identification [8]. Acoustofluidic devices pre-sort cells based on mechanical properties, enhancing transcriptome coverage uniformity while preserving membrane integrity [8].

Emerging applications include the assembly of synthetic biological circuits, where acoustic forces position DNA origami structures with nanometer precision for modular nanofabrication. Holographic modulation techniques enable simultaneous manipulation of multiple particle types, facilitating studies of inter-molecular interactions or pathogen-host cell binding kinetics [3]. Future directions emphasize integration with microfluidic organ-on-chip platforms to simulate physiological shear stresses during drug screening, leveraging the technique’s capacity for dynamic force modulation in three-dimensional microenvironments.

content.heading: 4.1 Mechanisms of Acoustofluidic Separation
content.content:
Acoustofluidic separation leverages acoustic radiation forces and microfluidic flow dynamics for high-precision sorting of biological samples. Ultrasonic standing waves in microscale channels create pressure nodes and antinodes, exerting forces on particles based on the Gor’kov potential, which depends on compressibility and density contrasts between particles and their medium, enabling sizeand density-based separation [12]. The non-contact nature preserves cellular integrity, minimizing interference, as shown in Raman-acoustofluidic platforms maintaining single-cell resolution during spectroscopic analysis [12]. This precision is crucial for single-cell analysis applications where cellular characteristics must be preserved.

As illustrated in Figure 4, the hierarchical structure of acoustofluidic separation mechanisms emphasizes the roles of acoustic forces, efficiency enhancements, and viscoelastic effects in optimizing sorting capabilities for biological samples. Separation efficiency is further enhanced by the Transmodal Fabry-Pérot Resonance (TFPR) principle, optimizing energy transfer between longitudinal and shear modes in anisotropic materials [4]. Wave momentum shaping techniques refine particle manipulation by adapting to real-time scattering conditions without prior knowledge of object characteristics [13]. This adaptability is critical for handling biological heterogeneity, supported by universal segmentation algorithms maintaining performance across diverse imaging modalities [3]. Integrating these techniques into acoustofluidic systems enhances sorting capabilities and opens avenues for complex biological analyses.

Viscoelastic effects significantly influence separation dynamics, particularly in complex biological fluids. Ultrasound Electrical Impedance Spectroscopy (UEIS) characterizes these effects by analyzing piezoelectric transducers’ frequency-dependent response, enabling adaptive optimization of acoustic parameters [8]. Integrating multimodal analysis frameworks, as employed in single-cell RNA distribution studies, bridges acoustic separation data with molecular profiling to resolve cellular subpopulations [7]. Computational models based on the Westervelt equation simulate nonlinear acoustic phenomena, essential for predicting particle trajectories in high-throughput sorting devices [11]. These computational advancements improve the predictability and reliability of acoustofluidic separation systems.

Emerging advancements focus on reconfigurable acoustic fields enabling parallel processing of multiple sample types within a single device. Holographic modulation techniques dynamically adjust pressure profiles for varying cellular mechanical properties, while kernel-based statistical methods quantify differential responses across manipulated populations [1]. Future directions include developing integrated lab-on-chip systems combining acoustofluidic separation with downstream genomic or proteomic analysis, leveraging the technique’s compatibility with single-cell resolution and minimal sample perturbation. Integrating these systems into clinical workflows represents a significant step forward in applying acoustofluidic technologies.

content.heading: 4.2 Single-Cell Analysis Platforms
content.content:
Acoustofluidic separation is transformative for single-cell analysis, enabling high-resolution isolation and characterization of individual cells with minimal perturbation. Acoustic forces integrated with microfluidic systems facilitate label-free sorting based on intrinsic biophysical properties, critical for resolving cellular heterogeneity [12]. Raman-acoustofluidic platforms exemplify this capability by combining acoustic trapping with spectroscopic profiling, achieving spatial confinement and molecular fingerprinting of single cells while maintaining high signal-to-noise ratios [12]. This advancement is significant in personalized medicine, where understanding individual cell characteristics can lead to more effective treatment strategies. The precision of acoustofluidic separation is enhanced by advanced signal processing models compensating for noise and artifacts in microscale environments. Deep learning frameworks integrated with model-based reconstructions improve trajectory prediction accuracy and sorting efficiency, particularly for rare cell populations [2]. Kernel-based statistical methods, such as Kernel Fisher Discriminant Analysis (KFDA), enable differential response analysis across manipulated cell populations, identifying phenotypic variations correlating with disease states [1]. These computational tools, complemented by universal segmentation algorithms, ensure robust cell identification and tracking during acoustic manipulation [3]. Combining these technologies enhances single-cell analyses’ accuracy and broadens applications in clinical diagnostics and research. Single-cell RNA sequencing benefits from acoustofluidic preprocessing, where mechanical propertybased presorting reduces transcriptome coverage bias and improves clustering accuracy. Confident clustering algorithms paired with PCA compression minimize misclassification errors during cell type identification, as demonstrated in tumor microenvironment studies [8]. The non-invasive nature of acoustic trapping preserves membrane integrity, enabling downstream functional assays requiring viable cells, validated by impedance spectroscopy during manipulation [8]. This advantage is critical for applications such as circulating tumor cell (CTC) analysis, where cell viability is essential for drug sensitivity testing and personalized therapy development. Maintaining cell viability while conducting analyses positions acoustofluidic techniques as a leading choice for cutting-edge biomedical research. Emerging applications leverage acoustofluidics for spatial transcriptomics and multi-omics integration. Multimodal AI frameworks combine acoustic separation data with single-cell omics, deciphering gene regulatory networks and cellular dynamics at unprecedented resolution [2]. Theoretical advancements in knowledge representation enhance single-cell datasets interpretation, bridging topology and generative processes through unified geometric and probabilistic models [10]. Future directions include developing integrated lab-on-chip systems coupling acoustofluidic sorting with real-time genomic or proteomic analysis, leveraging advancements in planar ultrasound sources and neural network-enhanced localization methods. Scalability challenges require innovations in transducer miniaturization and standardized fabrication protocols to transition these platforms from research tools to clinical diagnostics. Integrating these technologies into practical applications will shape the future landscape of single-cell analysis and its impact on personalized medicine.

content.heading: 5 Microfluidics and Lab-on-a-Chip Integration
content.content: The evolution of microfluidics has significantly advanced lab-on-a-chip technologies, enhancing the miniaturization and efficiency of analytical processes. This integration facilitates simultaneous multi-analysis in a compact format, revolutionizing diagnostics and therapeutics in fields such as medicine, environmental monitoring, and food safety. The key benefits of this integration include cost reduction, improved turnaround times, and increased accessibility to sophisticated analytical techniques. The following subsection delves into the advantages of miniaturization, emphasizing how reduced sample volumes and reagent usage enhance operational efficiency and throughput across various applications.

content.heading: 5.1 Benefits of Miniaturization
content.content:
Miniaturizing lab-on-a-chip devices through microfluidic integration offers substantial benefits, including reduced reagent consumption, enhanced throughput, and improved operational efficiency. Microfluidic platforms provide precise control over fluid dynamics at microscales, essential for applications requiring high precision, such as generating monodisperse microbubbles for diagnostic and therapeutic ultrasound [7]. Feedback-controlled systems optimize bubble production by integrating real-time optical measurements with adaptive regulation, ensuring consistent size distributions and production rates crucial for clinical applications [5]. These advances address scalability challenges while maintaining the precision required for targeted drug delivery and contrast-enhanced imaging, broadening microfluidic technologies’ clinical applicability.

Miniaturized systems’ reduced sample volumes lower reagent costs and enable high-density parallel processing, beneficial for rare cell analysis or point-of-care diagnostics. Dynamic characterization of microfluidic pumps demonstrates extended operational lifetimes and reduced electronic dependency, enhancing portability for field applications [11]. The laminar flow regime in microchannels facilitates predictable particle trajectories during acoustofluidic separation, improving sorting resolution and eliminating turbulent mixing artifacts common in macroscale systems. This precision is further validated in time-resolved velocity-pressure field measurements, optimizing device geometries [7]. These advancements underscore microfluidics’ potential to streamline processes previously constrained by physical limitations.

Throughput gains are achieved through multiplexed channel architectures and integrated sensing modalities, allowing simultaneous analysis of multiple samples. Feedback-controlled microbubble generators exemplify this synergy by combining hydrodynamic focusing with optical monitoring to sustain stable production rates exceeding conventional systems [5]. Passive pumping mechanisms enhance reliability by minimizing moving parts, demonstrated in field-deployable systems capable of prolonged operation without electronic components [11]. These innovations enable continuous biological sample processing with minimal user intervention, bridging laboratory research and clinical implementation. Future developments will focus on standardizing fabrication protocols to ensure reproducibility across manufacturing scales while integrating multimodal sensors for real-time quality control. The convergence of microfluidics with acoustic manipulation techniques promises further miniaturization of diagnostic workflows, particularly in single-cell analysis platforms requiring high resolution and throughput. Recent advancements in materials science and computational modeling are propelling lab-on-a-chip technologies toward greater autonomy and enhanced applicability in biomedical fields. Innovations such as self-powered polymeric micropumps and sophisticated statistical models derived from machine learning enable long-term fluid control and more effective data interpretation, broadening these systems’ potential for complex biological studies and applications [10, 11].

content.heading: 5.2 Case Studies of Lab-on-a-Chip Devices
content.content:
Lab-on-a-chip devices integrating acoustic manipulation have advanced biomedical applications, from diagnostics to therapeutic delivery. The Raman-acoustofluidic platform, combining acoustic trapping with Raman spectroscopy for label-free single-cell analysis, exemplifies this. It achieves spatial confinement and molecular profiling of individual cells with high signal-to-noise ratios, eliminating the need for fluorescent markers [12]. Its microfluidic design allows continuous flow operation, enabling high-throughput analysis of heterogeneous cell populations with minimal sample perturbation, valuable for cancer research and rare cell detection.

Feedback-controlled microbubble generators, utilizing microfluidic hydrodynamic focusing, produce monodisperse bubbles for ultrasound contrast enhancement and targeted drug delivery. These systems integrate real-time optical monitoring with adaptive regulation, ensuring consistent bubble size distributions critical for clinical applications [5]. The miniaturized design reduces reagent consumption while improving production stability compared to conventional methods, showcasing potential for point-of-care therapeutic applications. Time-resolved velocity-pressure field measurements within these devices validate computational fluid dynamics models, optimizing channel geometries for enhanced performance [7]. These advancements highlight microfluidic technologies’ profound impact on therapeutic interventions’ efficiency and effectiveness.

Acoustofluidic separation has been implemented in organ-on-chip platforms, where acoustic forces simulate physiological shear stresses to study cellular responses under dynamic conditions. Devices incorporating piezoelectric transducers fabricated via electrophoretic deposition (EPD) ensure precise control over lead zirconate titanate (PZT) microstructure and resonance characteristics for consistent acoustic field generation [5]. Impedance spectroscopy integration enables real-time monitoring of cell mechanical properties during manipulation, providing insights into disease mechanisms and drug efficacy [8]. These platforms bridge in vitro models and in vivo conditions, offering a scalable approach for preclinical testing that advances personalized medicine.

Field-deployable microfluidic systems demonstrate lab-on-a-chip technology’s versatility in resource-limited settings. Devices using passive pumping mechanisms achieve prolonged operation without electronic components, as evidenced by dynamic characterization studies showing extended operational lifetimes and reduced maintenance requirements [11]. These systems are particularly effective for infectious disease diagnostics, where portability and robustness are essential. Future developments aim to standardize fabrication protocols and integrate multimodal sensors, enhancing acoustic manipulation-enabled lab-on-a-chip devices’ reproducibility and functionality across diverse biomedical applications. This trajectory underscores microfluidic technologies’ adaptability and emphasizes their critical role in addressing global health challenges through innovative and accessible solutions.

content.heading: 6 Applications in Biomedical Engineering
content.content: Acoustic manipulation offers innovative solutions in biomedical engineering, significantly enhancing therapeutic efficacy and diagnostic precision. This section examines the roles of acoustic techniques in drug delivery, tissue engineering, and microbubble technology, highlighting their transformative potential in healthcare. The first subsection focuses on advancements in drug delivery, demonstrating how acoustic manipulation facilitates targeted treatments and improves patient outcomes.

content.heading: 6.1 Drug Delivery and Therapeutic Applications
content.content:
Acoustic manipulation revolutionizes targeted drug delivery by providing precise control over therapeutic agent release, crucial in complex biological environments [5]. Techniques like 3D-printed acoustic holographic lenses focus ultrasonic fields with sub-wavelength precision for localized drug release [4]. Neural network-enhanced localization further optimizes delivery precision, achieving $0 . 1 \mathrm { m m }$ accuracy in therapeutic scenarios [1]. These advancements enhance drug delivery efficacy, reduce side effects, and improve patient compliance.

Ultrasound electrical impedance spectroscopy (UEIS) aids in designing drug carriers by determining elastic moduli, ensuring optimal acoustic activation thresholds [8]. Polymeric micropumps in microfluidic systems enable sustained drug release through acoustic actuation [11]. These systems leverage acoustic radiation forces to manipulate asymmetrical drug carriers, accommodating complex geometries [4]. The adaptability of these systems supports personalized medicine, catering to individual needs.

Single-cell analysis techniques inform personalized therapies by resolving cellular heterogeneity [14]. Chemiluminescence modulation with acoustic triggering supports energy-efficient therapeutic monitoring, enabling closed-loop systems with real-time dosage adjustment [5]. Innovations in piezoelectric transducer technology enhance clinical translation, enabling depth-specific acoustic focusing for transdermal applications [5]. Future directions involve intelligent carrier systems combining acoustic responsiveness with biosensing, driven by advances in metamaterials and machine learning [3].

content.heading: 6.2 Tissue Engineering and Biomaterial Characterization
content.content:
Acoustic manipulation is pivotal in tissue engineering, offering non-contact methods for probing and assembling cellular constructs. The acoustic properties of poly(lactic acid) and its copolymers provide critical parameters for scaffold design [4]. Holographic cell stiffness mapping allows noninvasive mechanical characterization, maintaining cell viability [6].

Differential single-cell analysis platforms (DSCAP) integrated with acoustic manipulation enable real-time monitoring of cellular dynamics, valuable for studying stem cell differentiation and cancer invasion [7]. These platforms provide viscoelastic measurements without physical contact, essential for characterizing delicate constructs. Addressing algorithmic challenges in single-cell data analysis is crucial for advancing tissue engineering applications [14].

Emerging applications utilize acoustic forces for spatially controlled cell patterning, directing multicellular architecture assembly. Non-reciprocal transmission properties enable precise energy localization for scaffold stimulation, facilitating graded tissue development [5]. Future developments in hybrid systems combining acoustic manipulation with imaging modalities and machine learning are set to revolutionize tissue engineering, paving the way for complex tissue creation for regenerative medicine.

content.heading: 6.3 Diagnostics and Microbubble Technology
content.content:
Acoustic manipulation, via microbubble technology, enhances diagnostic imaging resolution and therapeutic delivery. Lipid-coated microbubbles serve as efficient ultrasound contrast agents, generating strong acoustic backscatter [5]. Feedback-controlled generation ensures consistent bubble size, addressing clinical ultrasound challenges [5]. Modeling approaches optimize bubble dynamics under focused ultrasound for diagnostics [4].

The Acoustic Shadow Moiré Interference (ASMI) technique combines ultrasound penetration with interference patterns, enabling imaging and manipulation of opaque specimens [12]. Time-resolved velocity-pressure field measurements inform microfluidic system design for contrast agent generation [7]. These technologies enhance diagnostic tools, allowing accurate pathological assessments.

The Transmodal Fabry-Pérot Resonance (TFPR) phenomenon improves diagnostic sensitivity by maximizing energy conversion between wave modes [4]. Applications leverage acoustic manipulation for molecular imaging, enabling biomarker detection with targeted ligands on bubble surfaces. Integrating these techniques with lab-on-a-chip platforms facilitates point-of-care diagnostics, combining microbubble-enhanced imaging with sample processing for rapid detection [4]. Advances in material science and transducer design, including 3D-printed holographic lenses, enable precise control of ultrasonic fields, enhancing biomedical ultrasound efficacy in non-invasive therapies [4]. Computational modeling and machine learning-assisted image reconstruction will refine the diagnostic accuracy and clinical applicability of microbubble technology.

content.heading: 7 Challenges and Future Directions
content.content: In advancing acoustic manipulation technologies, delineating specific technical and operational challenges is vital, as these affect scalability and reproducibility. Despite their promise in biomedical applications, complexities in implementation warrant a detailed examination of current limitations. These hurdles affect the adaptability of acoustic manipulation in dynamic environments, highlighting the need for innovative solutions.

content.heading: 7.1 Technical and Operational Challenges
content.content:
Adopting acoustic manipulation in biomedical applications faces significant technical and operational barriers. A major issue is the inability to reconfigure ultrasound fields rapidly and costeffectively, limiting adaptability [3]. Neural network-enhanced localization faces issues, especially when objects are near the imaging plane [1]. Fabrication inconsistencies in piezoelectric transducers, like PZT films, degrade performance due to non-uniform deposition [5].

Microfluidic integration adds challenges, as acoustic microstreaming affects particle stability and measurement precision [12]. In microbubble production, fluidic interactions between nozzles lead to instability [7]. The complexity in single-cell datasets complicates meaningful biological interpretation, and current cell segmentation benchmarks often prioritize accuracy over efficiency [10, 3].

Computational modeling also faces dual hurdles: deep learning requires extensive training datasets, while model-based algorithms are complex to implement [2]. Real-time wave momentum shaping, promising for dynamic settings, demands intensive computations and is noise-sensitive [13]. Additionally, specific equipment needs for differential single-cell analysis platforms limit adoption [7]. Willis coupling-induced techniques, though theoretically potent, demand precise control that complicates practical use [4].

These challenges are exacerbated by a lack of standardized protocols for device calibration and performance validation across biological systems. Developing universal testing frameworks that account for biological variability and system nonlinearities is critical for transitioning from laboratory to clinical settings. Addressing inconsistencies in transistor material fabrication, optimizing signal processing algorithms, and leveraging model-based deep learning techniques are essential for advancing the field [3, 5, 8, 6, 2].

content.heading: 7.2 Material and Design Limitations
content.content:
Material properties and device design limitations significantly hinder acoustic manipulation technology’s adoption in biomedical fields. Single-cell datasets, fraught with complexity and noise, often lead to misinterpretations due to analytical framework shortcomings [10]. Further, inconsistencies in piezoelectric material properties and fabrication processes, especially concerning polymers like poly(lactic acid), impact wave propagation and manipulation efficiency [4].

Device miniaturization introduces energy transfer and field uniformity challenges. While Transmodal Fabry-Pérot Resonance enhances energy conversion, precise control over anisotropic thicknesses is difficult in practice [4]. Microfluidic integration further complicates device design, requiring optimization of acoustic standing wave patterns and laminar flows, as exemplified by feedbackcontrolled microbubble generators facing challenges of increased polydispersity and instability [7].

Universal cell segmentation algorithms prioritize accuracy over computational efficiency, limiting real-time system utility [3]. Biocompatibility issues with processing media raise additional concerns. Addressing these limitations calls for advances in material science, fabrication protocols, and integrated design that balance performance across biomedical applications.

content.heading: 7.3 Algorithmic and Computational Improvements
content.content:
Enhancing computational modeling and algorithms is critical for precision in acoustic manipulation techniques. Deep learning shows promise in single-cell analysis with large datasets but faces implementation and dataset size challenges [8, 2]. Hybrid frameworks utilizing model-based and machine learning algorithms may improve adaptability [2].

Kernel-based statistical methods, such as KFDA, provide tools for analyzing manipulated cell populations, detecting phenotypic variations tied to diseases [1]. These are valuable when integrated with acoustic separation data for multimodal cellular heterogeneity analysis, enhancing computational robustness across settings [3].

Wave momentum shaping improves real-time adaptation in dynamic conditions, using generalized operators to tailor momentum transfer [13]. Despite this, computational efficiency poses challenges due to the need for intensive scattering matrix measurements.

Innovations in knowledge representation enhance single-cell dataset interpretation through integrated geometric and probabilistic models [10]. Multimodal AI frameworks further this by integrating acoustic data with omics for precise gene network analysis [2]. Future research includes developing adaptive control algorithms leveraging real-time feedback for manipulation optimization [8]. Scalable computational approaches are vital for transitioning acoustic technologies from research to clinical applications.

content.heading: 7.4 Interdisciplinary and Collaborative Research
content.content:
Progress in acoustic manipulation technologies requires interdisciplinary collaboration across physics, engineering, biology, and computing. Integrating deep learning with single-cell analysis exemplifies this synergy, enhancing manipulation classification and clustering while necessitating cooperation in algorithm development and biological validation [8]. Multimodal AI frameworks merge acoustic data with omics, demanding coordination among acousticians, biologists, and data scientists for detailed gene network analysis [2].

Material science innovations need collaboration between physicists and chemists, as shown in optimizing lipid-coated microbubbles. Nanobubble modeling requires acoustic physics and chemistry expertise to predict oscillations and thresholds [6]. Piezoelectric transducer fabrication benefits from material scientists and engineers’ cooperation, especially in controlling PZT microstructures [5].

Clinical translation highlights engineering-medical collaboration, as in holographic modulation for ultrasound field generation that aligns with anatomical constraints [3]. Feedback-controlled microbubble generators illustrate translational success by combining microfluidic engineering with radiological insights [5].

Computational challenges in acoustic manipulation reinforce the need for interdisciplinary approaches. Kernel-based statistical methods for analyzing cellular responses require joint development by statisticians and biophysicists, maintaining rigor and relevance [1]. Knowledge extraction from single-cell datasets benefits from topologists, computer scientists, and biologists collaborating on geometric and probabilistic models [10].

Emerging opportunities in organ-on-chip and precision medicine demand deep interdisciplinary integration. Acoustofluidic systems simulating shear stresses require coordinated advances across microfluidics, cell biology, and engineering [7]. Future research should emphasize shared frameworks and standards to enable collaboration, address challenges, and scale acoustic technologies for clinical use. Institutional support for cross-disciplinary training and funding is essential for sustained innovation.

content.heading: 7.5 Future Directions and Innovations
content.content:
Transforming acoustic manipulation for biological samples requires significant advancements in engineering, materials, and computation. In transducer design, extending wave momentum shaping for varied object manipulation and multiple target control is vital [13]. This requires optimization of acoustic beams for precise particle sorting in acoustophoresis [4]. Future architectures should incorporate multi-frequency patterns to reduce scattering artifacts in holographic systems for complex targets.

Material innovations should focus on responsive composites enhancing energy conversion and structural stability, especially in Fabry-Pérot systems. Optimizing differential single-cell platforms for broader contexts requires improved microfluidic interfaces and standard protocols [7]. Hybrid systems integrating piezoelectric polymers with metamaterials could enable simultaneous manipulation and mechanical characterization, addressing current mapping limitations.

Computational methodologies must bridge model-based and data-driven approaches through adaptive algorithms. Future frameworks should blend statistical methods with neural networks to handle single-cell data complexity while maintaining interpretability. Establishing benchmarks for 3D cell segmentation is essential for validating computational predictions in acoustic environments. This is crucial given advancements in deep learning for cell segmentation across diverse microscopy without manual adjustment, aiding disease modeling, drug testing, and diagnostics [10, 3, 14, 6, 8].

Interdisciplinary integration will propel acoustofluidics, combining planar ultrasound with microfluidic organ-on-chip to simulate microenvironments. Real-time impedance spectroscopy with machine learning can enable systems that adapt to cellular heterogeneity. Transferring technologies from research to clinics requires standardizing fabrication and performance metrics to ensure reproducibility. This dual focus is essential for reliability across institutions and applications, reflecting advancements in multi-modality cell segmentation and single-cell methodologies. Such innovations necessitate universally applicable algorithms and pipelines for diverse conditions, enhancing quantitative research and precision medicine. These convergences will establish acoustic manipulation as a cornerstone in precision medicine and future diagnostics.

content.heading: 8 Conclusion
content.content:
This survey has provided a comprehensive exploration of the advancements and applications of acoustic manipulation techniques within biological research and biomedical engineering, highlighting their transformative impact. By leveraging the principles of acoustic forces, such as primary radiation and secondary Bjerknes forces, researchers have achieved precise, non-contact control over biological samples, ranging from individual biomolecules to complex cellular structures. Device innovations, including holographic amplitude modulation and transmodal Fabry-Pérot resonance systems, have significantly enhanced the precision and adaptability of acoustic tweezers and ultrasonic particle manipulation. The fusion of acoustofluidic separation with microfluidics has revolutionized single-cell analysis, enabling label-free sorting and high-throughput processing while maintaining cellular integrity, thus underscoring the transformative potential of acoustic manipulation in advancing biological system understanding and application.

The scope of acoustic manipulation extends across diagnostics, therapeutics, and tissue engineering, showcasing a wide range of possibilities in the biomedical domain. Diagnostic applications benefit from microbubble technology and acoustic shadow moiré interference techniques, which improve imaging resolution and facilitate real-time visualization in opaque media, thereby enhancing the detection and monitoring of various biological processes. Therapeutic applications are advanced through targeted drug delivery systems and controlled release mechanisms, supported by sophisticated modeling of lipid-coated microbubble dynamics, enabling precise therapeutic interventions. Tissue engineering has been revolutionized by non-invasive mechanical characterization methods, such as holographic cell stiffness mapping, which offer spatial resolution of viscoelastic properties during construct development. These diverse applications illustrate the versatility of acoustic manipulation techniques in tackling complex biomedical challenges.

Despite these significant advancements, challenges in scalability, reproducibility, and computational modeling persist, hindering the widespread adoption of acoustic manipulation technologies. Issues such as material limitations, fabrication inconsistencies, and the inherent complexity of biological systems pose obstacles to progress and limit the efficacy of current methodologies. Future research should prioritize optimizing transducer design, establishing standardized protocols, and integrating machine learning algorithms for real-time adaptive control to enhance the precision and functionality of acoustic manipulation systems. Interdisciplinary collaboration will be crucial in bridging the gaps between physics, engineering, and biology, fostering innovations in organ-on-chip platforms and precision medicine applications. The ongoing evolution of acoustic manipulation holds promise for unlocking new frontiers in biomedical research and clinical practice, addressing critical challenges in diagnostics, therapeutics, and regenerative medicine.
